quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Surge’s contrarian scaling story
quotes.text: You guys hit a billion in revenue in less than four years with around 60 to 70 people. You're completely bootstrapped, haven't raised any VC money. I don't believe anyone has ever done this before.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete, rare data point that reframes what’s possible with a tiny team and no venture funding.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Surge’s contrarian scaling story
quotes.text: I used to work at a bunch of the big tech companies and I always felt that we could fire 90% of the people and we would move faster because the best people wouldn't have all these distractions.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A contrarian operating model: reduce headcount to increase speed by removing coordination and distraction overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Surge’s contrarian scaling story
quotes.text: So when we start Surge, we wanted to build it completely differently with a super small, super elite team.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A clear, actionable team-design principle: prioritize elite density over scaling org size.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Surge’s contrarian scaling story
quotes.text: People don't understand what quality even means in this space. They think you could just throw bodies at a problem and get good data, that's completely wrong.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A practical warning for AI/data work: quality doesn’t scale linearly with more annotators; it requires a different approach.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Surge’s contrarian scaling story
quotes.text: We're basically teaching our models to chase dopamine instead of truth.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A memorable critique of misaligned optimization: training incentives can push models toward engagement over accuracy or usefulness.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta helps companies of all sizes get compliant fast and stay that way with industry-leading AI, automation, and continuous monitoring.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Highlights a practical approach to compliance as an ongoing system (automation + continuous monitoring), not a one-time project.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta also helps you complete security questionnaires up to five times faster so that you can win bigger deals sooner.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Connects operational security work directly to revenue outcomes with a concrete speed improvement practitioners can target.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The result, according to a recent IDC study, Vanta customers slashed over $500,000 a year and are three times more productive.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Provides a specific ROI benchmark to justify investing in compliance automation and trust management.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building software for enterprises, you've probably felt the pain of integrating single sign-on, Skim, RBAC, audit logs, and other features required by big customers.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Names the common enterprise “deal blockers” teams should plan for early when moving upmarket.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: They're essentially Stripe for enterprise features.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Offers a memorable mental model for understanding WorkOS as infrastructure that abstracts complex enterprise requirements into APIs.

quotes.topic_title: AI leverage and tiny teams building huge companies
quotes.text: Yeah, so we hit over a billion of revenue last year with under 100 people. And I think we're going to see companies with even crazier ratios, like 100 billion per employee in the next few years.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark plus a provocative prediction that reframes what “leverage” could look like in AI-native companies.

quotes.topic_title: AI leverage and tiny teams building huge companies
quotes.text: I used to work at a bunch of the big tech companies and I always felt that we could fire 90% of people and we would move faster because the best people wouldn't have all these distractions.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive claim about organizational design: smaller teams can increase speed by reducing coordination and distraction costs.

quotes.topic_title: AI leverage and tiny teams building huge companies
quotes.text: One is that people are realizing that you don't have to build giant organizations in order to win.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A simple operating principle practitioners can apply when designing teams, processes, and hiring plans.

quotes.topic_title: AI leverage and tiny teams building huge companies
quotes.text: If you think about it, fewer employees means less capital. Less capital means you don't need a raise. So instead of companies started by founders who are great at pitching and great at hyping, you'll get founders who are really great at technology and product.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A causal chain mental model linking team size to capital needs to founder incentives—useful for strategy and fundraising decisions.

quotes.topic_title: AI leverage and tiny teams building huge companies
quotes.text: And instead of products optimized for revenue and what VCs want to see, you'll get more interesting ones built by these tiny obsessed teams.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A prediction that challenges VC-driven product optimization and argues for focus-driven craftsmanship as a competitive advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding the Silicon Valley PR/fundraising machine
quotes.text: We basically never wanted to play the Silicon Valley game.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A clear contrarian stance that frames the company’s deliberate avoidance of the typical PR/fundraising playbook.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding the Silicon Valley PR/fundraising machine
quotes.text: What did you dream of doing when you were a kid? Was it building a company from scratch yourself and getting in the weeds of your code and your product every day? Or was it explaining all your decisions to VCs and getting on this giant PR and fundraising hamster wheel?
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for founders to choose between product-building focus and the distraction of fundraising/PR cycles.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding the Silicon Valley PR/fundraising machine
quotes.text: And so it made things more difficult us because the only way we were going to succeed was by building a 10 times better product and getting word of mouth from researchers.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Actionable go-to-market guidance: if you skip hype and fundraising, you must win via a 10x product and organic advocacy.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding the Silicon Valley PR/fundraising machine
quotes.text: I always thought it was really important for us to have early customers who were really aligned with what we were building, and who really cared about having really high quality data, and really understood how that data would make their AI models so much better because they were the ones helping us.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A methodology for early-stage growth: select deeply aligned early customers to create tight feedback loops and improve the product faster.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding the Silicon Valley PR/fundraising machine
quotes.text: So these are people who basically just buying our product because they knew how different it was and because it was helping them rather than because they saw something in that current [inaudible 00:08:52].
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive customer-selection insight: avoiding hype can filter in buyers who value real differentiation and outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: What Surge does: teaching models via human data
quotes.text: We essentially teach AI models what's good and what's bad.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Frames post-training as value/behavior teaching, not just more training data—useful for aligning teams on the purpose of human feedback.

quotes.topic_title: What Surge does: teaching models via human data
quotes.text: So we train them using human data, and there's a lot of different products that we have, like SFT, RHF, rubrics, verifiers, RL environments, and so on and so on, and then we also measure how well they're progressing.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Lists a practical post-training toolkit and emphasizes measurement as part of the loop, not an afterthought.

quotes.topic_title: What Surge does: teaching models via human data
quotes.text: So essentially we're a data company.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A crisp positioning statement that highlights data quality and evaluation as the core product in modern model improvement.

quotes.topic_title: What Surge does: teaching models via human data
quotes.text: What you always talk about is the quality has been the big reason you guys have been so successful, the quality of the data.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Underscores a key lever practitioners can focus on: data quality as a primary driver of model performance and company outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Defining and measuring “high-quality” training data
quotes.text: I think most people don't understand what quality even means in this space. They think you could just throw bodies at a problem and get good data and that's completely wrong.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Challenges the common assumption that scaling headcount automatically yields high-quality training data.

quotes.topic_title: Defining and measuring “high-quality” training data
quotes.text: If you don't think deeply about quality, you'll be like, "Is this a poem? Does it contain eight lines? Does it contain the word, moon?" You check all of these boxes, and if so, sure. Yeah, you say it's a great problem. But that's completely different from what we want. We are looking for a Nobel Prize-winning poetry.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Provides a concrete example of why box-checking “quality” metrics fail and sets a higher target standard for data excellence.

quotes.topic_title: Defining and measuring “high-quality” training data
quotes.text: And so we have to build all of this technology in order to measure it, like thousands of signals on all of our workers, thousands of signals on every project, every task.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Describes an operational methodology: instrument quality measurement at scale using many signals per worker and task.

quotes.topic_title: Defining and measuring “high-quality” training data
quotes.text: So we are looking at your keyboard strokes. We are looking how fast you answer things. We are using reviews, we are using code standards, we are using... We're training models ourselves all on the outputs that you create, and then we're seeing whether they improve the model's performance.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Lists specific, actionable signals and closes the loop by validating quality via downstream model performance improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Defining and measuring “high-quality” training data
quotes.text: One is you want to remove all of the worst of the worst webpages. So you want to remove all the spam, all the just low quality content, all the pages that don't load, and so it's almost like a content moderation problem. You just want to remove the worst of the worst.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Introduces a two-stage quality framework: first filter out the worst (moderation), then separately identify the best.

quotes.topic_title: Why Claude excelled: data choices and taste
quotes.text: I think people don't realize that there's almost like this infinite amount of choices that all the frontier labs are deciding between when they're choosing what data goes into their models.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Highlights a key mental model: model quality often comes from many small, compounding data-selection decisions rather than one obvious factor.

quotes.topic_title: Why Claude excelled: data choices and taste
quotes.text: Some companies, they see these benchmarks and they're like, "Okay, for PR purposes, even though we don't think that these academic benchmarks matter all that much, maybe we just need to optimize for them anyways because our marketing team needs to show certain progress on certain standard evaluations that every other company talks about, and if we don't show good performance here, it's going to be bad for us even if ignoring these academic benchmarks makes us better at the real tasks."
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A contrarian warning that optimizing for benchmarks can be a marketing-driven trap that hurts real-world performance.

quotes.topic_title: Why Claude excelled: data choices and taste
quotes.text: Other companies are going to be principled and be like, "Okay, yeah, no, I don't care about marketing. I just care about how my model performs on these real world tasks at the end of the day, and so I'm going to optimize for that instead."
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: choose objective functions and evaluations that reflect real user tasks, not just standard leaderboards.

quotes.topic_title: Why Claude excelled: data choices and taste
quotes.text: One of the things I often think about is that there's a... It's almost like there's an art to post training. It's not purely a science.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Frames post-training as an iterative craft where judgment calls matter, not a purely mechanical optimization process.

quotes.topic_title: Why Claude excelled: data choices and taste
quotes.text: But again, I don't think that makes for good poetry, so certain frontier labs, the ones with more taste in sophistication, they will realize that it doesn't reduce to this six set of checkboxes and they'll consider all of these kind of implicit, very subtle qualities instead, and I think that's what makes them better at this at the end of the day.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Argues that “taste” and subtle qualitative criteria can outperform rigid checklist-style optimization, especially for writing and creative tasks.

quotes.topic_title: Benchmarks vs real-world progress and human evals
quotes.text: Yeah, so I don't trust the benchmarks at all.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A contrarian stance that challenges the default reliance on benchmark scores as a proxy for real capability.

quotes.topic_title: Benchmarks vs real-world progress and human evals
quotes.text: And the other part of it is these benchmarks at the end of the day, they often have well-defined objective answers that make them very easy for models to hill-climb on in a way that's very different from the messiness and ambiguity of the real world.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Explains a key failure mode: objective benchmarks invite optimization that doesn’t transfer to ambiguous real-world work.

quotes.topic_title: Benchmarks vs real-world progress and human evals
quotes.text: I think one thing that I often say is that it's kind of crazy that these models can win IMO gold medals, but they still have trouble parsing PDFs.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A memorable example illustrating the gap between benchmark success and practical usefulness in messy workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Benchmarks vs real-world progress and human evals
quotes.text: Yes, so the way we really care about measuring model progress is by running all these human evaluations.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Actionable measurement guidance: prioritize expert human evals over benchmark leaderboards to track real progress.

quotes.topic_title: Benchmarks vs real-world progress and human evals
quotes.text: And because or searchers or annotators, they are experts at the top of their fields, and they are not just giving your responses, they're actually working through the responses deeply themselves, they are... Yeah, they're going to evaluate the code that it write. They're going to double check the physics equations that it writes.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for evaluation: domain experts deeply verify outputs (e.g., code, equations) rather than “vibe” scoring.

quotes.topic_title: AGI timelines and why the last mile is hard
quotes.text: I think people don't realize that there's a big difference between moving from 80% performance to 90% performance to 99% performance to 99.9% performance, and so on, and so on.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A reliability-scaling mental model: the “last mile” from good to near-perfect performance is disproportionately hard, shaping realistic deployment and roadmap expectations.

quotes.topic_title: AGI timelines and why the last mile is hard
quotes.text: And so in my head, I probably bet that within the next one or two years, yeah, the models are going to automate 80% of the average LL6 software engineer's job.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A concrete near-term forecast practitioners can use for workforce planning, tooling investment, and workflow redesign around partial automation.

quotes.topic_title: AGI timelines and why the last mile is hard
quotes.text: It's going to take another few years to move to 90%, and another fewer to 99%, and so on, and so on.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A staged adoption framework that encourages planning in capability plateaus (80→90→99→99.9) rather than assuming linear progress to AGI.

quotes.topic_title: AGI timelines and why the last mile is hard
quotes.text: So I think we're closer to a decade or decades away than [inaudible 00:23:03].
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A contrarian timeline anchor that challenges short-horizon AGI expectations and supports longer-term risk and strategy planning.

quotes.topic_title: Wrong incentives: leaderboards, engagement, and AI slop
quotes.text: We're basically teaching our models to chase dopamine instead of truth.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for how misaligned incentives can steer model behavior away from accuracy and usefulness.

quotes.topic_title: Wrong incentives: leaderboards, engagement, and AI slop
quotes.text: But the thing is, like I was saying earlier, they're not carefully reading or fact-checking. They're skimming these responses for two seconds and picking whatever looks flashiest.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Explains why crowd-voted leaderboards can reward superficial presentation over correctness—useful when designing evals.

quotes.topic_title: Wrong incentives: leaderboards, engagement, and AI slop
quotes.text: The easiest way to climb LLM Arena, it's adding crazy boating. It's doubling the number of emojis. It's tripling the length of your model responses, even if your model starts hallucinating and getting the answer completely wrong.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A concrete example of how leaderboard optimization can directly incentivize verbosity and style hacks that degrade truthfulness.

quotes.topic_title: Wrong incentives: leaderboards, engagement, and AI slop
quotes.text: "The only way I'm going to get promoted at the end of the year is if I climb this leaderboard, even though I know that climbing it is probably going to make my model worse and accuracy [inaudible 00:24:57] following."
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Highlights an organizational incentive failure practitioners can watch for: internal rewards tied to metrics that harm real quality.

quotes.topic_title: Wrong incentives: leaderboards, engagement, and AI slop
quotes.text: And every time we optimize for engagement, terrible things happened.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A cautionary rule-of-thumb from social media that can guide AI product teams away from engagement-maximizing objectives.

quotes.topic_title: Product choices like Sora and the path matters
quotes.text: I think there is a question of what products they're building and whether those products themselves are something that kind of help or hurt humanity.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A practical evaluation lens: judge AI companies by the real-world impact of the products they choose to ship.

quotes.topic_title: Product choices like Sora and the path matters
quotes.text: It's like which companies would build Sora and which wouldn't?
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic question for inferring a company's values and strategic direction from its product bets.

quotes.topic_title: Product choices like Sora and the path matters
quotes.text: I think it's almost like, do you care about how you get there?
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that means-and-ends matter in AI development, not just the end goal.

quotes.topic_title: Product choices like Sora and the path matters
quotes.text: would you sell tabloids in order to fund, I don't know, some other newspaper?
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A memorable analogy for questioning whether revenue-generating “low-road” products create misalignment with long-term mission.

quotes.topic_title: Product choices like Sora and the path matters
quotes.text: it's possible that it has negative consequences in of itself that will harm the long-term direction of what you're trying to achieve, and maybe it'll distract you from all the more important things, so yeah, I think that the path you take matters a lot as well.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Actionable caution: short-term product choices can create externalities and distraction that degrade long-term outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Anti-playbook startup advice: mission over pivots
quotes.text: So yeah, I would say don't pivot. Don't put scale. Don't hire that Stanford grad who simply wants to add a hot company to your resume, just build the one thing only you could build, a thing that wouldn't exist without the insight and expertise that only you have.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A contrarian anti-playbook that prioritizes founder-unique insight and mission over common VC-driven tactics like pivoting, blitzscaling, and resume-driven hiring.

quotes.topic_title: Anti-playbook startup advice: mission over pivots
quotes.text: And you see these buy to [inaudible 00:29:34] companies everywhere now. Some founder who was doing crypto in 2020, and then pivoted to NFTs in 2022, and now they're an AI company. There's no consistency, there's no mission, they're just chasing valuations.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A concrete example-pattern of “trend-chasing” pivots that illustrates how frequent pivots can signal lack of mission and long-term coherence.

quotes.topic_title: Anti-playbook startup advice: mission over pivots
quotes.text: But if you're constantly pivoting, you're not taking any risks. You're just trying to make a quick buck.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A reframing that challenges the conventional wisdom that pivoting is inherently “lean,” arguing it can be a way to avoid real risk-taking.

quotes.topic_title: Anti-playbook startup advice: mission over pivots
quotes.text: So yeah, I think the only way you build something that matters that's going to change the world is if you find a big idea you believe in and you say no to everything else.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A simple methodology for focus: commit to a single big idea and actively reject distractions, even when alternatives look easier or trendier.

quotes.topic_title: Anti-playbook startup advice: mission over pivots
quotes.text: Yeah, I absolutely think that you have to have huge ambitions, and you have to have a huge belief in your idea that's going to change the world, and you have to be willing to double down and keep on doing whatever it takes to make it happen.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A practitioner-oriented mental model for building “generational” companies: ambition + conviction + sustained doubling down through difficulty.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Imagine starting a project at work. And your vision is clear, you know exactly who's doing what, and where to find the data that you need to do your part.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical mental model for project setup: clarity of ownership plus instant access to needed data.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Coda's collaborative all in one workspace, you get the flexibility of docs, the structure of spreadsheets, the power of applications, and the intelligence of AI all in one easy to organize tab.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concise framework for evaluating an “all-in-one” tool by the four capabilities it combines (docs, spreadsheets, apps, AI).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And more than 50,000 teams trust Coda to keep them more aligned and focused.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete adoption data point that signals broad usage and perceived value for team alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: he talked about how LLMs almost are kind of a dead end, and he thinks we're going to really plateau around LLMs because of the way they learn.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A counter-narrative that challenges the assumption that scaling LLMs will keep delivering major gains indefinitely.

quotes.topic_title: Beyond LLMs: reinforcement learning environments
quotes.text: I believe that in the same way that there's a million different ways that humans learn, we need to build models that can mimic all of those ways as well.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A practical mental model for AGI progress: diversify training paradigms to mirror the many modes of human learning rather than betting on one approach.

quotes.topic_title: Beyond LLMs: reinforcement learning environments
quotes.text: An RL environment is essentially a simulation of real world. So think of it like building a video game with a fully fleshed out universe. Every character has a real story, every business has tools and data you can call, and you have all these different entities interacting with each other.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Defines RL environments in a vivid, implementable way that helps practitioners conceptualize how to design training worlds for end-to-end agent behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Beyond LLMs: reinforcement learning environments
quotes.text: So for example, we might build a world where you have a startup with Gmail messages, and Slack threads, and Jira tickets, and GitHub PRs, and a whole code base. And then suddenly AWS goes down. And Slack goes down. And so, "Okay. Model, well, what do you do?" The model needs to figure it out.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A concrete, tool-rich scenario showing how to stress-test agents on realistic operational incidents rather than narrow benchmarks.

quotes.topic_title: Beyond LLMs: reinforcement learning environments
quotes.text: You have all these models that seem really smart on isolated benchmarks, they're good at single step tool calling. They're good at single step instruction following. But suddenly you dump them into these messy worlds where you have confusing Slack messages and tools they've never seen before, and they need to perform right actions and modify the [inaudible 00:36:06] and interact over longer time horizons where what they do in step one affects what they do in step 50. And that's very different from these kind of academic single step environments that they've been in before, and so the model just fails catastrophically in all these crazy ways.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning: strong benchmark performance can mask catastrophic failure in long-horizon, messy, real-world workflows—arguing for environment-based evaluation/training.

quotes.topic_title: Beyond LLMs: reinforcement learning environments
quotes.text: This is the next stage, and it's not the case that the previous methods are obsolete, this is, again, just a different form of learning that compliments all the previous types, so it's just like a different skilled model not only to learn how to do.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for practitioners: treat RL environments as additive to SFT/RLHF/rubrics rather than a replacement, shaping a blended training roadmap.

quotes.topic_title: Evolution of post-training: SFT, RLHF, rubrics, evals
quotes.text: So SFT stands for supervised fine-tuning. So again, I think often in terms of these human analogies, and so SFT is a lot like mimicking a master and copying what they do.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Provides a sticky mental model for what SFT is optimizing for—imitation—helping practitioners choose it when they want faithful replication of exemplars.

quotes.topic_title: Evolution of post-training: SFT, RLHF, rubrics, evals
quotes.text: And then RLHF became very dominant. And analogy there would be like sometimes you learn by writing 55 different essays and someone telling you which one they liked the most.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Clarifies RLHF as preference learning over many candidates, emphasizing the practical implication that you need diverse samples to learn from comparisons.

quotes.topic_title: Evolution of post-training: SFT, RLHF, rubrics, evals
quotes.text: And then I think over the past year or so, rubrics and verifiers have become very important. And rubrics and verifiers are like learning by being graded and getting detailed feedback on where you went wrong.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Highlights a newer post-training methodology—rubric/verifier-based feedback—that practitioners can use to target specific failure modes with structured grading.

quotes.topic_title: Evolution of post-training: SFT, RLHF, rubrics, evals
quotes.text: Yeah. So I think evals often covers two terms. One is you are using the evaluations for training because you're evaluating whether or not the model did a good job, and when it does do a good job, you're rewarding it.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Distinguishes evals-as-training-signal from evals-as-measurement, a useful taxonomy for designing pipelines and avoiding confusion about what “evals” means.

quotes.topic_title: Evolution of post-training: SFT, RLHF, rubrics, evals
quotes.text: And then there's this other notion of evals where you're trying to measure the model's progress like, okay, yeah, I have five different candidate checkpoints and I want to pick the one that's best in order to release it to the public. So going to run all these evals on these five different checkpoints in order to decide which one is best.
quotes.speaker: Edwin Chen
quotes.context: Gives a concrete operational example of evals for checkpoint selection, reinforcing evals as a release/quality gate rather than only a training tool.
